coredata.dc:title: On the convergence of the cluster model for O/Ni(100)
coredata.dc:creator: Bauschlicher, Charles W.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Chemisorption of oxygen onto the Ni (100) surface is modelled using a three-layer Ni41 cluster. The convergence of the cluster model is considered by comparing the results of the Ni41 cluster to the previously studied two-layer Ni25 model for O/Ni(100). The O vibrational frequency is only slightly changed by the addition of the third layer, while the height of the O above the surface is reduced by 0.11 Å, increasing the disagreement with experiment. The O binding energy is reduced to less than half that for the Ni25 cluster.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 129, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19 September 1986 ON THE CONVERGENCE OF THE CLUSTER MODEL FOR 0/Ni(100) Charles W. BAUSCHLICHER Jr. NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA 94035, USA Received 21 February 1986; in final form 24 July 1986 Chemisorption of oxygen onto the Ni(lOO) surface is modelled using a three-layer ?41 cluster. The convergence of the cluster model is considered by comparing the results of the ?41 cluster to the previously studied two-layer ?25 model for 0/Ni(100). The 0 vibrational frequency is only slightly changed by the addition of the third layer, while the height of the 0 above the surface is reduced by 0.11 A, increasing the disagreement with experiment. The 0 binding energy is reduced to less than half that for the ?35 cluster. 1. Introduction Recent experiments on small metal clusters and their chemistry show [1-4] that the properties vary strongly with cluster size. It is only for clusters of about 40 atoms that their properties begin to con- verge toward those of the bulk. This strong variation in chemistry with cluster size might seem to contra- dict the success [ 5,6 ] of the small metal clusters in modeling the properties of perfect crystal faces of bulk metal. In these cluster models the metal-metal bond lengths and cluster geometry are fixed at those of the bulk, which can be very different from the geometri- cal parameters for the free clusters [7,8]. Since part of the difference between the chemistry of small metal clusters and that of the bulk can be a result of differ- ences in cluster geometry, using bulk geometry for the cluster models may improve the convergence of their properties toward those of the bulk. The question of how rapidly the properties com- puted using these cluster models converge toward the bulk has been of interest, and the conclusions as to the correct cluster size have varied somewhat [9,10]. For atomic adsorption on some systems [9], it appears that the vibrational frequency, <Ue> normal to the surface and the height above the surface, R^, converge quite quickly with cluster size, but that the binding energy converges more slowly. It was con- cluded [9] that when all metal atoms involved in bonding to the adsorbate have their nearest neigh- bors, the We and R^_ have converged. This suggests that a two-layer cluster would be sufficient to model most chemisorption processes. For example, to model the chemisorption ofO into a four-fold hollow of the (100) face ofNi would require a two-layer 21-atom cluster, with 12 atoms in the first layer and 9 in the second layer, Ni2i(12,9). Upton and Goddard (UG) have modeled [ 10] the 0/Ni(100) system using a 20- atom cluster, ?20(6,8,6). The UG cluster contains about the same number of Ni atoms as that based upon the nearest neighbor criterion. However, they have used a cluster which contains three layers. Since the three-layer cluster contains the same number of atoms as the two-layer cluster, some of the first-layer nearest neighbors to the bonding Ni atoms are miss- ing. Allison and Goddard [11] have used a three- layer 14-atom cluster to investigate CO/Ni(100). Their cluster contains Ni atoms at the comers and faces of a cube, i.e. a three-layer cluster, ?14(5,4,5). Since the CO is adsorbing directly above a Ni atom, the nearest neighbor model would suggest that a ?9(5,4) cluster would be sufficient. However, recent work [12,13] onH:,0,NH3andCOonNi(100),all adsorbing directly above a Ni atom, has shown that a two-layer cluster yields a repulsive interaction of the ligand and surface. If third-layer atoms are added the repulsion is greatly reduced. Because of this effect of the third layer on the description of the adsorption of NH3, HzO and CO, it was decided to investigate the effect of adding a third layer to the ?35 cluster 586 Volume 129, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19 September 1986 used to investigate the coverage dependent effects of 0 adsorption [14-17], and it is found that vibra- tional frequency is slightly changed, the height above the surface is reduced by 0.11 A, and the Z>e decreases by a factor of two. 2. Computational details The goal of the previous studies [14-17] of 0/Ni(100) was to understand the origin of the shift in (Ue as the oxygen coverage was increased from 0.25 ML (ap(2x2) LEEDpattem) to0.5 ML (ac(2x2) LEED pattern) [18]. To model this process it was necessary to be able to consider two different 0 cov- erages. The cluster had to be sufficiently large to allow the chemisorption of one and five 0 atoms. The 25- atom cluster used in the previous work is pictured in fig. 1. For the low coverage, one 0 was chemisorbed onto the center of the cluster. All the Ni at this adsorption site have their nearest neighbors. For the high coverage, the four surrounding 0 are added. Since the Ni atoms bonded to the surrounding 0 atoms do not have all their nearest neighbors, the geometry of the outer 0 was fixed and only the cen- tral 0 reoptimized at the higher coverage. Extensive tests also showed [14-17] that the oxide state, where all 0 orbitals are doubly occupied, either as lone pairs or in bonding orbitals with the Ni, is the lowest state at all coverages. In this work, the computational approach follows that used in the previous two-layer Ni cluster calcu- Fig. 1. The ?2505 cluster used to model the c(2x2)/Ni(100) coverage, the adsorbate atoms are cross hatched. The p(2x2) coverage is modeled by eliminating the four doubly cross hatched adsorbate atoms. The ?4105 cluster adds a third layer which is identical to the first layer. lations. The calculations are restricted to a treatment of the oxide state at the self-consistent-field (SCF) level. Previous work [17] showed that the inclusion of correlation stabilized the oxide state relative to the radical state (i.e. an open-shell orbital on 0), but that the height above the surface and vibrational fre- quency were not strongly affected. However, 0/Ni(100) is quite ionic, thus one would expect cor- relation to increase the binding by significant amount (the correlation contribution to the electron affinity of 0 is 2 eV). Therefore, convergence of the >e i" this work reflects convergence for the SCF approxi- mation, which will not necessarily be equal to exper- iment. The Ni core electrons, including the 3d electrons, are removed using the modified effective- core potential (MEP) developed by Melius [19]; this reduces Ni to a one-electron atom. Our previous work [ 14,15 ], as well as other theoretical calculations [ 20 ] show a small effect of the 3d, and therefore support including it in the MEP. The Ni valence basis set is that developed by Melius and includes functions to describe the 4s and the 4p function, (4s3p/2slp). The 4p basis functions are needed to describe the impor- tant 4s-4p hybridization. Since it is important to include the 4p functions at the site of adsorption, the elimination of the 4p functions on the third-layer Ni atoms, is compared to a cluster in which all Ni atoms have the 4p functions included. The third-layer atoms are far from the site of adsorption and this mixed cluster is found to yield results similar to the cluster of all Ni atoms with the 4s and 4p basis functions. The 0 basis set is Dunning's contraction [21 ] of the Huzinaga primitive set [22], and includes the dif- fuse p function optimized by Dunning and Hay [ 23 ] for 0~. Even after reducing the Ni to a one-electron atom, clusters with such a large number of atoms lead to very large calculations; to avoid the problems associated with storing the two-electron integrals, a modified [24] version of the Oslo DISCO program [ 25 ] has been used throughout this work. The reduction of Ni to a one-electron atom is a drastic approximation, and a comparison between all- electron and MEP calculations showed some differ- ences [14-17]. To improve the MEP approxima- tion, two corrections were considered. One correction is based upon the breakdown in the assumption that the 0 does not penetrate into the orbitals included in the MEP, i.e. a breakdown in the Zen-ective assump- 587 Volume 129, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19 September 1986 tion. While the second is based upon a comparison of a frozen orbital all-electron calculation on Ni^X" with the description obtained for the MEP + X -. The corrections improved the agreement between the all-electron and MEP calculations, as well as the agreement between the cluster and experimen- tal results. The corrections decreased rapidly strongly increasing Ni-0 distance, thus the third-layer Ni atoms will hardly contribute to the correction. Since the goal of this work is to consider the convergence of the properties with cluster size, we compare the uncorrected results. The inclusion of the correction will not change the differences observed between the two clusters, but rather shift the results for both clus- ters in a similar manner. The ?41(16,9,16) cluster is formed by adding a 16-atom third layer to the previous ?25(16,9) clus- ter. This third layer is identical to the first layer. This gives the ?41 cluster D4h symmetry. However, once 0 is added, or when the 4s only basis set is used for the third layer, the symmetry is reduced to C4v; thus C4v symmetry notation is used throughout. The geometry and ?-N1 bond lengths are fixed at the bulk values [26]. Since the magnetic properties are expected to arise from the d electrons, the lowest doublet state is determined for the bare cluster, Ni4|(;>A|)...5a26a!3b22b25e4. (1) There is also a low-lying 2{^ ^ state arising from the excitation 6ai -> la;. This state is about 0.4 eV higher. To this ?41 cluster one 0 atom is added to the center of the top layer, and the lowest oxide state was found to be ?4,0(^1 )...7a?8a!3b?2bj6e4. (2) This state is consistent with bonding of the 0 to the lowest state of ?41. The height above the surface is optimized, and the c^e computed using a parabolic fit: w^=(a/my'2, (3) where a is the force constant for motion normal to the surface and m is the mass ofO, i.e. the Ni atoms are assumed to be infinitely massive and there is no phonon coupling with the 0 vibration. For the high coverage, the five 0 are added to the cluster, see fig. 1, and three low-lying states were found, ?4,05(1^, )...10a2! la; lai4bf5bjl0e4, (4) Ni4l05(2Bl)...lla21a23b24b!5b210e4 (5) and ?4105(2^, )...10a2! la^a^b^bjIOe4 . (6) The 1 ^i and ^i states are virtually degenerate, while the 2 ^i state is about 1.3 eV higher in energy. 3. Results and discussion The results for the ?41 cluster, as well as those for the ?25 cluster are summarized in table 1. The addi- tion of the third layer causes an 0.11 A contraction in the R^_. This increases the disagreement with experiment [27], 0.86 0.07 A. Previously it was noted [ 14-17], that due to the MEP approximation, the computed R^ is too short. Two different correc- tions to the MEP improved the computed 7?^, bring- ing the computed R^ (0.83 and 0.78 A) into better agreement with experiment, but still being at the lower range of the experimental value. The contrac- tion in R^ with the addition of the third layer seems to worsen the model. The computed We shows a smaller change with the addition of the third layer, a 7% increase in (Oe com- pared to the 19% reduction in RJ_. Neither the a)e computed for the ?350 nor ?410 cluster agrees with the EELS experiment [18]. However, the calcula- tions are for a rigid Ni lattice, which is not the case for the metal surface. Andersson et al. [18] have per- formed lattice dynamics calculations where the Ni-Ni and Ni-0 potentials were adjusted until computed and experimental EELS spectra agree. If the Ni atoms are made infinitely massive in the lattice dynamics calculations, the Ni phonon coupling with the 0 vibration is eliminated, and a direct comparison with the cluster results is obtained. This lattice dynamics value [18], 351 cm"', is in better agreement with the cluster calculations. The same MEP correction which increased R^ for ?250, also increased ( e for ?250 by up to 120 cm~1. Since neither the (Ue for the ?250 nor for the ?410 agree with the lattice dynamics calculations, and the MEP corrections for ?25 are twice as large as the difference between either cluster (Ue and that of the lattice dynamics calcula- tions, it is not possible to judge if adding the third 588 Volume 129, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19 September 1986 layer has improved the model. While the changes in both 7?^ and a)e are relatively small, the change in De with the third level is extremely large, ^(?41-0) is only 46% of that of the Ni^O cluster. Perhaps this result should not have been too surprising. The Z>e tor the NizsO cluster was about equal to the value reported by UG for their NizoO three-layer cluster, and it is known that the neglect of the 4p functions by UG leads to a short R_^ and too strong a bond. Thus the >e foi" ^e cluster with the 4p functions would have been expected to be smaller than UG's, but in fact was the same. Therefore the different choice of the cluster size and shape, and the difference in basis sets must have con- tributed to a cancellation of errors, such that the ?25 and the ?20 cluster of UG yield the same >e. Thus suggesting that the ?410 is closer to the converged cluster value at the SCF level. It should also be noted that the UG three-layer ?20 cluster yields a R^ in between the values obtained for two-layer N125 and three-layer ?41 clusters. Clearly, the basis set, the number of first-layer neighbors, and the presence of a third layer all affect the description of chemisorption. The charge on the 0 gives a guide to the nature of the ?-0 bonding. In the previous work [15-17], the increase in the 0 population with increased cov- erage was used to explain the origin of the shift in (de- It is found that our models for low coverage, ?350 and ?410, show an 0 population decrease of 0.17 electrons with the third layer. This change with the third layer is larger than the increase in the charge on the central 0 as the outside four 0 are added to the ?250 cluster. While the relative change in the 0 population between ?25 and ?41 is not as large as that found for Z>e, it is of the same magnitude as the coverage dependent population change (chemical change in the bonding) between ?350 and N12505, which was used to interpret the shift in (D, between the p( 2 x 2) and c( 2 X 2) LEED patterns. While the change in the results with the addition of the third layer is rather large, it is interesting to note that the addition of a third layer which contains Ni atoms described by the smaller 4s only basis set, yields results which are quite similar to those obtained with the larger basis set. The use of the 4s only basis set for the bottom layer represents a con- siderable savings, for the bare ?41 cluster the num- ber of basis functions is reduced from 205 to 157. For a process which is proportional to the fourth power of the number of basis functions, this repre- sents almost a factor of three reduction in the work. It is also possible that under some circumstances the 4p functions on the second layer atoms could also be Table 1 Comparison of the results for the two-layer ?250, and the three-layer ?410, clusters ? 0" ?4,0 ?4,0 mixed b) Exp. ^i(A) &><; (cm"') D. (eV) 0 charge 0.58 280 3.85 -0.85 0.47 300 1.79 -1.02 0.45 275 1.93 -1.13 0.86 0.07c) 423 " ' ?,,0, Oc(outerO)0 0 charge (center) 0 charge (outer) 2.04 -1.05 -0.65 1.94 -0.57 -1.00 "Ref. [17]. b) Mixed indicates that the (4s/2s) basis set is used for the third layer. "Ref. [27],EXAFS. d) Ref. [ 18], experimental EELS value of the p(2x2) LEED pattern. cf Lattice dynamics calculations to separate the 0 vibration from the surface phonons, yields a value 351 cm~', which should be more similar to the value computed in this work where the Ni lattice was rigid. 0 Computed as [De(Ni,-Os) -Dc(Ni,-0)]/4. 589 Volume 129, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19 September 1986 deleted, but that has not been tested. The initial intent of this work was to consider the change in CD, with coverage. The ?410, cluster has the outer 0 at the value optimized for ?410, R^ = 0.9 bohr, and central 0 with R^ =0.7 5 bohr. For this geometry the low-lying states were determined. The charge on the 0 atoms is virtually identical for the three states, but different from that found for ?2505. For Ni4i0^, the charge on the central 0 decreases with the addition of the outside oxygen atoms, whereas it increases for the ?25 cluster. The charge on the cen- tral oxygen of the ?41 cluster is similar to the charge on the outside 0 atoms in ?25, while the charge on the outside 0 in ?4, is about that of the central 0 in ?25. Initially the difference in charge between the inner and outer 0 atoms on the N{2505 cluster was attributed to the edge effects making the outer 0 populations less reliable. However, the change in the 0 population between ?250,, and ?4,0,, suggests that effect of cluster convergence is of the same mag- nitude as the edge effects, even for the 25-atom clus- ter. The outside 0 atoms in ?2505 are bound by substantially less than the 0 in ?250, while the out- side 0 in ?4,05 are bound by more than the 0 in ?410. Clearly, ?41 is giving a different description of the system than is N125. The optimization of R^ and determination of<Ue was not performed because the extremely slow con- vergence and large cost per iteration made it clear that a prohibitive amount of computer time would be required to converge the SCF calculations to the accuracy needed to determine (Oy The reduction of the basis set on the third-layer Ni atoms would nat- urally reduce the time, however it would still be sig- nificant. Furthermore, it is not clear that ?41 is in fact a better model for 0/Ni (100). For other systems [9,13], it has been found that the convergence of properties with cluster size is not monotonic, just as found in experiments for small metal clusters. The agreement between the experimental and computed results for ?250^ and ?255,,, [15-17] suggests that ?25 is a good model for the ?(100) surface. Thus it was felt that it did not warrant the computer time to further test the model. It is clear, however, that while the N125 may be a good model for the surface, it is not converged with respect to cluster size. 4. Conclusions The addition of the third layer to a ?25 cluster shows that the 25-atom cluster is not converged with respect to cluster size. The addition of the third layer reduces the binding energy by a factor of two. For lone pair ligands, the third layer moves charge off the top layer, which increases the bonding [12,13]. For 0 which draws charge from the cluster, it is not sur- prising to find that the third layer reduces Z>e. The populations show a more negative 0 in ?410 than for ?250. The height above the surface and 0 vibra- tion normal to the surface show smaller changes, which is consistent with previous work which sug- gests that these properties converge quite rapidly. When the higher coverage is modelled with ?4105, the changes in 0 population are opposite to those observed for the smaller cluster; the 0 charge decreases with higher 0 coverage for ?41. Consid- ering the agreement between Ni25Y^ and available experimental data, ?25 appears to be a good model for the metal, however, it is not converged with respect to cluster size. Acknowledgement I would like to acknowledge the support of the NAS project. All the calculations reported in this manu- script were performed on the NAS CRAY XMP-12. References [ 1 ] S.C. Letters 49(1982) 142. 591 gests that ?25 is a good model for the ?(100) surface. Thus it was felt that it did not warrant the computer time to further test the model. It is clear, however, that while the N125 may be a good model for the surface, it is not converged with respect to cluster size. 4. Conclusions The addition of the third layer to a ?25 cluster shows that the 25-atom cluster is not converged with respect to cluster size. The addition of the third layer reduces the binding energy by a factor of two. For lone pair ligands, the third layer moves charge off the top layer, which increases the bonding [12,13]. For 0 which draws charge from the cluster, it is not sur- prising to find that the third layer reduces Z>e. The populations show a more negative 0 in ?410 than for ?250. The height above the surface and 0 vibra- tion normal to the surface show smaller changes, which is consistent with previous work which sug- gests that these properties converge quite rapidly. When the higher coverage is modelled with ?4105, the changes in 0 population are opposite to those observed for the smaller cluster; the 0 charge decreases with higher 0 coverage for ?41. Consid- ering the agreement between Ni25Y^ and available experimental data, ?25 appears to be a good model for the metal, however, it is not converged with respect to cluster size. head.ce:title: On the convergence of the cluster model for O/Ni(100)

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: NASA Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CA 94035, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Chemisorption of oxygen onto the Ni (100) surface is modelled using a three-layer Ni41 cluster. The convergence of the cluster model is considered by comparing the results of the Ni41 cluster to the previously studied two-layer Ni25 model for O/Ni(100). The O vibrational frequency is only slightly changed by the addition of the third layer, while the height of the O above the surface is reduced by 0.11 Å, increasing the disagreement with experiment. The O binding energy is reduced to less than half that for the Ni25 cluster.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Critial reviews in solid state and material sciences
